summary: This is a 2022 opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan addressing Ghislaine Maxwell's post-trial motions following her conviction. The court denies most motions but grants her claim that three conspiracy counts are multiplicitous, concluding they constitute a single conspiracy with Jeffrey Epstein. The court will enter judgment on only one of the three conspiracy counts. This is a court opinion/order (Document 657) filed in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (Case 1:20-cr-00330). The court denies Maxwell's Rule 29 motion for acquittal on several counts but finds Counts One and Five multiplicitous with other counts, vacating judgment on those. It also denies a motion claiming constructive amendment or prejudicial variance. The document analyzes the evidence presented at trial, particularly regarding the conspiracy and sex trafficking charges. This is a court opinion/order (Document 657) from the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, filed on April 29, 2022. It addresses the defendant's motion for a new trial, specifically rejecting her claim that a constructive amendment of the indictment occurred during her trial. The court analyzes jury instructions, evidence presented, and a jury note related to Counts Three and Four (Mann Act violations). This is a court opinion/order (Document 657) filed on April 29, 2022, in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (Case 1:20-cr-00330-AJN). The document denies Maxwell's post-trial motions, including a Rule 29 motion for judgment of acquittal and motions based on claims of constructive amendment/variance and pre-indictment delay. The court addresses jury instructions, evidence related to abuse in New Mexico, and the sufficiency of evidence supporting the convictions. This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan resolving a motion in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The order denies motions regarding variance and pre-indictment delay, grants a motion regarding multiplicity of counts, and confirms the conviction on Counts Three, Four, and Six. It also notes the sentencing date for Ghislaine Maxwell remains scheduled for June 28, 2022.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant convicted on five counts for her role in a scheme with Jeffrey Epstein to groom, recruit, and traffic underage girls for sexual abuse from 1994 to 2004.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as the Defendant's (Ghislaine Maxwell's) continuous coconspirator in a decade-long unlawful agreement to groom and sexually abuse underage girls.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge sitting by designation who authored the opinion and order on Maxwell's post-trial motions.

persons.name: Lisa Rocchio
persons.context: A doctor who testified as an expert witness about the typical steps in sexual abusers' grooming of minors.

persons.name: Jane
persons.context: A victim/witness referred to as 'Jane' who testified about sexual abuse by Epstein in New Mexico. Her testimony and the notice provided to the defense are discussed.

persons.name: Carolyn
persons.context: A victim/witness referred to as 'Carolyn'. The government presented evidence that she was a victim of the conspiracy and she testified about her cooperation.

persons.name: Annie
persons.context: A witness who testified about sexual contact that occurred in New Mexico; the court gave a limiting instruction regarding her testimony.

persons.name: Virginia
persons.context: A person who recruited Carolyn and performed sexualized massages for Epstein; flight records show she was under 18 when she met Maxwell and Epstein.

persons.name: Juan Alessi
persons.context: Testified that Maxwell approached him in a parking lot and he later saw her at Epstein's Palm Beach residence.

persons.name: Albert Pinto
persons.context: A deceased architect who built/renovated Epstein's residences. The defense claims his absence due to pre-indictment delay caused prejudice.

persons.name: Roger Salhi
persons.context: A deceased architect who built/renovated Epstein's residences. The defense claims his absence due to pre-indictment delay caused prejudice.

persons.name: Markham
persons.context: A deceased property manager for Epstein. The defense speculates he could have testified that 'the Countess', not Maxwell, created a household manual.

persons.name: Lynn Fontanilla
persons.context: A deceased live-in housekeeper for Epstein in New York. The defense speculates she could have testified about Maxwell's and Epstein's habits.

persons.name: Larry Visoski
persons.context: A pilot for Epstein who testified at trial about delivering flight manifests.

persons.name: David Rodgers
persons.context: A witness who testified at trial, listed among those who worked for Epstein.

persons.name: Michael Casey
persons.context: A deceased talent agent mentioned in the defendant's prior briefing as an absent witness due to pre-indictment delay.

persons.name: Joseph Recarey
persons.context: A deceased detective from the Palm Beach Police Department mentioned in the defendant's prior briefing as an absent witness.

connections.description: Partners in a decade-long criminal conspiracy to entice, transport, and traffic underage girls for sexual abuse, employing a uniform 'playbook'.
Maxwell transported Jane to New York for sexual abuse by Epstein, assisted with travel arrangements, and was present during some abuse.
Maxwell scheduled sexualized massage appointments for Carolyn with Epstein, paid her, and touched her breasts while commenting on her body.
Maxwell traveled with Annie to New Mexico, encouraged her to massage Epstein, and gave her a massage during which she touched Annie's breasts.
Maxwell met Virginia when Virginia was under 18; Virginia later recruited Carolyn and performed sexualized massages for Epstein.
Epstein sexually abused Jane from age 14, gave her money and gifts, and transported her to New York for abuse.
Epstein received sexualized massages from Carolyn when she was under 18, paid her, and discussed sexual topics with her.
Markham was Epstein's property manager. An email chain indicates Maxwell worked with Markham to create a household manual.
Pinto was an architect who built/renovated Epstein's residences.
Visoski was a pilot for Epstein who delivered flight manifests to his office.

events.title: Indictment of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was indicted for her participation in a scheme with Jeffrey Epstein to entice, transport, and traffic underage girls for sexual abuse.

events.title: Conspiracy Period
events.description: The timeframe during which Maxwell and Epstein conspired to violate federal statutes targeting sexual abuse of minors.

events.title: Sex Trafficking Conspiracy Period
events.description: The specific period for Count Five, charging conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of individuals under eighteen.

events.title: Court Denies Pretrial Multiplicity Motion
events.description: The court denied Maxwell's pretrial motion to dismiss conspiracy counts as multiplicitous, ruling it was premature.

events.title: Court Again Denies Multiplicity Motion
events.description: The court again denied Maxwell's motion on multiplicity grounds, reiterating that the Double Jeopardy Clause prohibits multiple punishments, not indictments.

events.title: Transportation and Abuse of Jane
events.description: Jane, age 14-17, was transported by Maxwell and Epstein from Palm Beach to New York, where she was sexually abused. Maxwell assisted with travel arrangements.

events.title: Sex Trafficking of Carolyn
events.description: Maxwell recruited and scheduled Carolyn, a minor, to perform sexualized massages for Epstein in exchange for money.

events.title: Flight with Virginia
events.description: Flight records show Epstein, Maxwell, and Virginia traveling together in December 2000, when Virginia was under 18.

events.title: Start of 'Pyramid Scheme' Phase
events.description: The government described 2001 as the beginning of a 'pyramid scheme of abuse' where Maxwell could call girls to schedule massage appointments directly.

events.title: Court Denies Rule 29 Motion
events.description: The court denies Maxwell's motion for acquittal on Counts Three, Four, and Six, but vacates judgment on multiplicitous Counts One and Five.

events.title: Jane's travel to New York
events.description: Jane, under age 17, was enticed to travel from Florida to New York for purposes of sexual abuse at Epstein's New York residence, as alleged in the indictment.

events.title: Flight to New Mexico
events.description: A flight from New York to New Mexico is referenced in the context of jury deliberations and testimony about sexual activity.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
events.description: The criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell took place, resulting in her conviction on multiple counts including conspiracy and transportation of minors for illegal sexual activity.

events.title: Government discloses Jane's New Mexico abuse recollection
events.description: The Government provided notes of an interview with Jane where she recalled abuse in New Mexico, giving the defense notice more than three weeks before trial.

events.title: Trial Testimony on New Mexico Abuse
events.description: Witness Jane testified at trial about being sexually abused by Jeffrey Epstein at his ranch in New Mexico.

events.title: Jury Note Inquiry
events.description: The jury sent a note during deliberations (referred to as the 'July note') that the defendant argued showed confusion about basing a conviction on New Mexico conduct alone. The court found the note ambiguous.

events.title: Court Denies Post-Trial Motions
events.description: The court issued this opinion denying Ghislaine Maxwell's Rule 29 motion for acquittal and motions based on constructive amendment/variance and pre-indictment delay.

events.title: Court Order on Motions
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues an order denying motions regarding variance and pre-indictment delay, granting a motion regarding multiplicity of counts, and confirming conviction on specific counts.

events.title: Scheduled Sentencing for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The sentencing date for Ghislaine Maxwell remains scheduled.

keyFacts: The court found the three conspiracy counts (Counts One, Three, and Five) to be multiplicitous, meaning they charge the same single conspiracy offense with Jeffrey Epstein, violating the Double Jeopardy Clause.
The government conceded Counts One and Three were multiplicitous but argued Count Five was a distinct conspiracy; the court rejected this, finding it part of the same overarching agreement.
The conspiracy employed a single 'playbook' to groom and sexually abuse underage girls from 1994 to 2004, constituting one continuous conspiracy with multiple victims.
The court denied Maxwell's motions for acquittal based on insufficient evidence, constructive amendment/variance of the indictment, and prosecutorial delay.
Judgment will be entered on Count Three alone among the conspiracy counts, but the jury's factual findings of guilt on all counts remain valid.
The court found Counts One and Five multiplicitous with other counts, meaning the jury effectively found the same criminal conduct multiple times; judgment was entered only on Count Three.
The government's theory at trial presented a single decade-long conspiracy between Maxwell and Epstein to sexually abuse underage girls, using a common 'playbook' of grooming.
Substantial evidence supported Maxwell's convictions, including victim testimony about travel arrangements, scheduling of sexualized massages, direct payments, and physical touching.
The court denied Maxwell's Rule 29 motion for acquittal on Counts Three (conspiracy to transport minors), Four (transportation of Jane), and Six (sex trafficking of Carolyn).
The document references a 'pyramid scheme of abuse' starting around 2001, where Maxwell directly called minors to schedule appointments for Epstein.
The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's motion for a new trial, rejecting her claim that a constructive amendment of the indictment occurred.
The core of criminality for Counts Three and Four was a scheme by Epstein and Maxwell to cause underage girls to travel to New York with intent to engage in sexual activity violating New York law.
A key issue was a jury note asking about guilt under Count Four if Maxwell aided only a return flight from New Mexico, not the flight to New Mexico where intent for sexual activity was formed.
The court found the jury note ambiguous and responded by referring the jury back to the original charge, which correctly stated New York law as the predicate.

Testimony about sexual activity in states other than New York (like New Mexico and Florida) was admitted as relevant evidence of intent for the New York-based scheme, not as independent bases for conviction.
The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's motion for judgment of acquittal (Rule 29), finding the guilty verdicts were supported by witness testimony and documentary evidence.

The court rejected Maxwell's claim of constructive amendment/variance regarding jury instructions, concluding the jury was properly instructed that only a violation of New York law (Penal Law Section 130.55) could be the predicate for the Mann Act counts.
The court addressed testimony about sexual abuse in New Mexico, finding the defense had adequate notice (received Nov. 6, 2021) and was not unfairly surprised or prejudiced.

The court denied Maxwell's pre-indictment delay claim, finding she failed to prove the government intentionally delayed for tactical advantage or that she suffered actual and substantial prejudice from lost evidence or deceased witnesses.

The defense argued prejudice from missing documents (flight, financial, phone, property records) and deceased witnesses (architects, property manager, housekeeper), but the court found these claims speculative and insufficient.
The court denied the Defendant's (Ghislaine Maxwell's) motions based on alleged variance and pre-indictment delay.
The court granted the Defendant's motion regarding multiplicity, finding Counts One and Five multiplicitous with Count Three.
The court will enter a judgment of conviction on Counts Three, Four, and Six against Ghislaine Maxwell.
The document states the criminal conduct involved a decade-long unlawful agreement between Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein to groom and sexually abuse underage girls.
Ghislaine Maxwell's sentencing date remained scheduled for June 28, 2022.
